job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Syracuse, NY
pros:
Mediocrity wins the day! If you don't want to work hard, you make mistakes, or you just don't care, this is the place for you!
Benefits are pretty good - better if you are in an exempt position.
cons:
Pay is WAY BELOW the regional average for the work you are expected to perform. Bachelor's degree required for jobs that pay $14-$18/hour. Not even close to fair for the job responsibilities and skills required.
Management is CLUELESS. 
Salary increases are the bare minimum (1%) for non-exempt employees and are not performance-based. Reviews aren't read by anyone in the organization and have nothing to do with salary increases. Raises are based on favoritism. Promotions are non-existent.
Non-exempt employees are treated poorly by exempt employees. There is definite discrimination among exempt and non-exempt staff.
Pay does not match the skills and education required to perform job duties.
If you do a good job, your reward will be more work without the pay increase that should accompany the work increase.
Non-exempt employees pay more for some benefits that are included in exempt employees benefit packages. Salaries are so low that they offer a "Schedule B" payment plan for people who are paid so little that they can't afford their benefit package.

Syracuse University has a terrible history of racism - not only with their faculty, but also with the Alumni. African-Americans only take up roughly 9% of the total alumni. Add that with last year's #notagainsu movement where SU blantant racist actions have caused the expulsion of multiple African-Americans, but you also have people spray painting swastikas and the N word on random walls. Even in the place where I work, you have faculty doing the same thing.

There's very little diversity here. It's mostly white smiling faces. Where I work, there's about 80 or 90 people total, but only 4 people of color including myself. Previous African-Americans who worked in my department have all left because of the constant berating the surrounding staff has put them through, and I'll be one of those people leaving soon.

pros:
Benefits are pretty good, especially the remitted tuition seem to be in the top tier of education institutions. Full tuition coverage for your dependents after 3 years worked (even at other approved colleges!)

The university wields a lot of power and influence in the community, so you can get a sense of feeling proud to be working at a very prominent institution in the area.

The cost of living in the area is pretty cheap.
cons:
As has been said, the bureaucracy is very real with plenty of policies and hierarchies to get through to be able to do some. There isn't too much room for empowerment for 'lower' employers to do what needs to be done, which can be extremely frustrating.

Full-time at the university is at 37.5 hours instead of 40, which to me feels like more of a cost-savings for the university, but it can really add up in lost time/money for employees.

In general, I don't feel paid well enough for the job I do.

The weather can be so terribly dreadful in the winter...this cannot be overstated! Bring plenty of Vitamin D. It's not too bad in the late spring and summer, but expect to go without seeing the sun for weeks at a time.

The university is VERY behind the times when it comes to implementing technology. Examples: we just upgraded to Windows 7 a few weeks ago from Windows XP, I have seen our current office telephones on old episodes of Mary Tyler Moore, and there are plenty of things that needlessly still require papers/forms.

review_title: Great place to launch career - if you can handle the cold
pros: Educational benefits - the university encourages ongoing development of employees and of family members - a big plus.  Summer hours for administrative staff are appreciated, diversity of religious holidays observed.  Excitement of working within an educational environment means there are always fresh ideas and young blood to keep things exciting.  Discounted tickets to major sporting events (or at least, the only sporting events that matter in Syracuse!).  Access to university resources (physical / intellectual as well as human) allow you to expand in your job.  Depending on where you work, facilities can be very welcoming.  Stability of work force is nice.
cons: Parking is very expensive and walking is highly unpleasant when the weather is bad.  The stability of the work force is a plus but can sometimes lead to entrenched thinking that is not always helpful.  As with any university, campus politics can sometimes be a drag, but are avoidable if one chooses not to get involved.  Technology challenges among the different schools was a little frustrating to deal with - again, perhaps related to campus politics.  While general development opportunities abound, career advancement may require moving out to move up - and the dearth of similar organizations in upstate New York can make that difficult.

pros: Organized structure and team to work with.
cons: Big organization at the university

pros: great place to study full time
cons: i have no problem with Syracuse

pros: good professors and students. nice environment
cons: it is cold in winter

pros: good co-workers, decent benefits, relaxed atmosphere
cons: some micro managing/poor leadership/no advancement

pros: Working at SU has been a fantastic experience. Everybody in my department has been incredibly welcoming and kind. When I first came to SU in 2010, many others in my department gave me suggestions on where to go and took me out to the more notable restaurants in town. Though I know many university positions are department-specific and, thus, you would mostly be dealing with others in your department, my experiences with people in other departments has been equally as pleasing.
cons:
I think one of the major issues with SU has to do with parking. Of course, this is an issue at many large universities, however it seems that wherever you might park on campus, you'll have a good-sized walk through the snow (during winter, of course) to get to where you need to be. I don't know how that situation could ever be rectified, though. 

I think some of the buildings could certainly be updated on the inside.

pros:
Benefits are amazing, great 401k, great health insurance, and remitted tuition is a dream.
My department is great, my director was brilliant and on top of that just a general good person.
The one coworker I work with the most is very supportive.
Lots of opportunities to learn new things through remitted tuition and then put them into action.
It's comfortable to have a position at the university, breaks are great and it feels like an accomplishment to have a good job with a respected employer.
cons:
Like all universities there is a lot of bureaucracy.
Not enough interdisciplinary collaboration.
Not enough follow through and urgency in accomplishing things.
We're a university, some sort of standard best practices information should be available to everyone, I feel like I'm just kind of feeling my way around in the dark.
Budgetary concerns, we don't have the money to spend on things that businesses would have.

review_title: Important Departments Understaffed, Overworked, Poor Priorities
pros: The benefits are great. Lots of perks for staff on campus. People who generally like to help others.
cons: Pay. Understaffed. Upward mobility. Caseload. Culture of fear. Must pay for parking. Poor training.

review_title: 4 years in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering Department as research / teaching assistant during MS / Ph.D. programs.
pros: Relatively good pay for research / teaching assistants (RAs, TAs) in the engineering college, with a good mix of high-profile projects to choose from.  Good health care packages available to student employees (SU Blue).  Good compensation for conference travel and some research incentives offered.
cons: Limited resources available to student researchers (i.e. restricted machine shop, few usable high-power computers, etc.).  Extremely limited spread of courses in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering Department for graduate students.  Too much emphasis on publishing research papers early and often, rather than publishing excellent papers.

review_title: It's a gamble; you are trading a living wage for the chance that your children will want to attend this university.
pros: If you have pre-college-age children and if you meet the requirements, your children (if accepted) have the opportunity to attend tuition-free. The company contribution to retirement is above average.
cons: The salary is pitiful; the medical benefits are expensive compared to other large employers; although they make a big show of charging less for medical benefits to lesser-paid employees, in reality the difference it is only a few dollars a month. If you are not faculty or employed in athletics, you have very little value to this company and you will be reminded of that in every paycheck.

pros: I was a graduate assistant for four different departments while getting three graduate degrees. Pros are the great health benefit and access to all the standard facilities that most of the companies don't have (gym, pool, etc).
cons:
- It is a fairly large university and your work environment largely depends on where you work. If your boss sucks, your work will suck. (But that is not really about this this university.) 
- The winter here is brutal. 
- Parking is limited.

review_title: Working as an office assistant in the SU Food Services office has been a pleasant experience over the past 5 years.
pros: I have worked in the same office since my freshman year of college here at Syracuse University. I am now almost 1 year graduated and my bosses have been kind enough to hire me on as a temp during this transition time of trying to find a job within my degree. My superiors were always understanding to my needs when I was working as a student; although I am no longer a student, they are flexible, understanding, and a pleasure to work with.
cons: While working as a temp, I do not receive any benefits. Other than that, I am very grateful to be working this job because the pay is very good, especially when compared to the same type of job working somewhere else.

review_title: Great teammates, programs and lateral support.  Poor senior management and respect.
pros: The Institute is filled with very talented and highly qualified people.  Employees at the lowest level bend over backwards to help one another and work well together.  The Institute puts out world-class programs and services that focus on furthering the post service lives of veterans and their families.
cons: Senior management is out of touch with their people and don't effectively utilize their talented employees.  Senior members of the team value the funders of the Institute over their employees and core customer; the veteran.  Lots of closed door conversations and decisions made with little input from junior members.

review_title: Great job, with great benefits such as free tuition for dependents.
pros: generous time off, plus paid green days (vacation days) for time periods that the students are not on campus, for example the university will give you extra paid days off around Christmas time due to students not being there, so it doesn't make sense to run the campus.
cons: The university makes staff and faculty pay for their parking passes, the price depends on the location of the lot you need to park. the university may not honor parking pass during dome event, which is very frustrating if you need to get to work and can't park anywhere .

pros: The students are interesting and will work.
cons: Both mid-level and upper administration have created an atmosphere that lacks any sense that you are a valued employee.  Therapists are forced to work, nights, weekends, on-call without compensation.  Case loads are overwhelming without any qualified Directors to manage the day to day issues.  Total lack of leadership.  Lots of in-fighting among staff which causes people to hide in their caves called offices.

review_title: Syracuse University - some good, some bad, and lots of administrators with side pet projects
pros:
Strong faculty, varied but acceptable student body, good facilities. The campus is pretty.
Cost of living in Syracuse is very low, and there is a reasonable amount to do. Lovely parks and regional attractions. 
The new chancellor looks promising.
cons:
The biggest problem when I was there was continuing administrative bloat, both in terms of numbers and the side projects that are only loosely (if at all) related to academics. This drew time, attention, money, and other resources away from academics. 

Syracuse the city is very poor with a fairly high crime rate. Lots and lots and lots and lots and lots of snow.

pros: Easy to land a part time job here if you are a student with a little time on your hand. There are a number of search tools that can help people find positions, and the interview process, if any, is a breeze.
cons: Inter-department politics and funding practices make it impossible to get promoted, and in turn your resume becomes a long list of entry level positions. Too many layers in the chain of command meant that no job at the entry level put you in contact with people who were allowed to think for themselves, even if they had great ideas. The environment is completely inflexible, its impossible to make a change to the way anything operates, even the most mundane things take eight levels of approval.

pros: A good working environment with health insurance benefits. The administrative staff is very supportive and provides all possible help to get things done as long as it is technically and legally possible.
cons:
Limited possibility of collaboration as most of the research groups are based on their language, ethnicity, place of origin, and of course technical expertise. Less intra-group diversity.

Some professors make students work without salary, and employment benefits like tuition waiver, health benefits, etc. They get their research work done from masters students for 2-3 months without paying (saying that it is probation) and then fire students saying they are no good. Beware of such professors and practices cause you need to be paid for your labor.

pros: I worked as a Graduate Assistant while in school.  The positive was that the schedule was flexible, my boss was good about communicating needs and expectations.  The full-time professional staff was helpful and nice.  People really like working here.  The tuition credits were helpful, too.
cons: I was confused about insurance options, particularly as to how it overlapped with the student insurance.  Sometimes, there were scheduling conflicts between work and other school requirements, but there were general work-arounds negotiated.  Not many cons.

pros: This University has been great to work for. The educational benefits are great, especially for anyone with children approaching college age, or for professionals seeking to acquire additional college degrees. Salaries are fair depending on your position, but overall, a great school to work for.
cons: The school is going through some changes and change is never easy for everyone. New policies and procedures are not as rewarding as they once were and several have quit or taken early retirement. Not necessarily a con, but definitely a change.

review_title: Good benefits, tough for an entry-level
pros: The benefits are pretty great - including 10% contribution to your 401k without having to put in anything. Pretty much everyone knows about SU which makes you more marketable.
cons: It's a very political institution. The higher you are, the more money you make. It's not a very welcoming place for someone new in their career. The pay is pretty low and there is little room for advancement. You see a lot of entry-level employees leave after a few years as there isn't really a reason to work harder, as raises/bonuses don't exist.

review_title: SU has potential, but falls short
pros: The benefits at SU are terrific and comprehensive.  There is also a nice grant writing series that trains researchers on writing successful grants that I found useful.
cons: SU is a very on and off place to work as a researcher.  Some of the groups are terrific, with collaboration and scientific rigor, others are terrible groups to work in with little or no support.  In the biomedical and chemical engineering department, the postdocs have very little communication, and science seems to take a back seat to the egos of the professors in the department.  The collaborative environement is minimal, and the financial support lacking as well.  Overall, I'm disappointed to say that I cannot reccomend SU as a place to advance your career as a scientist in training.

pros:
Senior management that has ignored infrastructure and university issues is leaving.
Lots of opportunities to improve and make a real impact.
Higher Education is changing so it is exciting to be involved in those changes.
So many different areas you can work in at the university that it gives people a lot more flexibility to try out different types of jobs and find your own calling
cons:
Politics at the higher management level is worse than corporate america.
Sometimes the size of the organization makes it move very slowly but this could be because of current management which is leaving.

pros: Good courses, good professors and competitive environment, the university has a very good infrastructure. The location is good and very near to Syracuse downtown.
cons: Very far from the big cities of USA like New York, Boston, Chicago; so finding jobs nearby is not very easy. One has to move to the California to find jobs. However, the university offers good education so its not a bad deal.

pros:
• Very nice pay for the amount of work you do (literally stand all day)
• Paid training is provided and the co workers are very cool to work with
• The AMs (Assistant Managers) are also students and are very easy to get along with
• Food provided each shift
• Opportunities for promotions
cons: Meal breaks are only 15 minutes long. The general employees you will be supervising are usually not motivated, have attitudes, and just don't like working. I wish we were able to be more strict with rules and have the more superior figure towards GE's rather than working as peers.

review_title: Worked as GAFC server (SU food services)
job_title: Goldstein Alumni Faculty Center Server in Syracuse, NY
pros: Working on campus (right next to Bird Library) so it's super convenient; working with other students; free meals every shift; amazing kitchen staff, regular shifts. Probably one of the better food service jobs you could get on campus. It's also good experience for getting another server job if you don't have any.
cons: Can't accept tips as a server despite full service expectations, which some students forget as customers. There was a change in management a short while ago that made it a much stricter and less enjoyable environment to work in.

pros: Good entry-level opportunities, generous time off, excellent tuition benefits if you have dependents, friendly people in the lower ranks.
cons: No opportunity for advancement if you are staff. There is a "grass is always greener" attitude where any opportunity to hire outside of the SU community is considered better. Little to no pay raises. Expensive parking. Lots of politics the higher up you get.

review_title: Typical private university - all the pros and cons!
pros:
Benefits are very good, especially the free tuition benefit for dependents. Tuition remission for staff is also good, but difficult to find the time to take courses. 

Highest level leadership is visionary. Engagement with the community is important though challenging.
cons: Typical political infighting can be challenging as in any academic environment. There are oppoortunities for collaborations across college boundaries that go unused.

review_title: nice place to work nice benefits
pros: if you work in a lab where the lab focus matches your research interests then it's a great place to work. I found my time here fulfilling and productive.
cons: if you work as a Teaching assistant (which in most likely hood is the support you will get as a grad student in this undergrad heavy institution), it has great resources to help you in the field but it takes up a lot of your time at the cost of your research. If you work as a research assistant/postdoc then you will get enough time to be productive.

review_title: Rigid Worklife But Great Benefits and Location
pros: Employee at a University adds to a lot of cultural opportunities, networking, connections, and events. Cost of living is low, and NY benefits from many different projects. The collection that SU holds in its repositories is amazing, and definitely a treat to work on their cultural gems.
cons: The rigid structure of Bird Library (where I was employed) made it nearly impossible to cut through red tape. A new presiding Director of the library was sworn in so hopefully that helps.

pros: Great benefits to include affordable medical/dental, as well as ample vacation, personal, and sick time off. Depending on the job there might be a flexible schedule, opportunities to work from home when needed, and the ability to move up or into new roles within the university, easily.
cons: Parking isn't the best and you have to pay for it. It's academia so there are a lot of people who might look down on you. If you work with students, the parents can be difficult.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Syracuse, NY
pros: I have enjoyed teaching undergraduates at Syracuse University. Being a Teaching Assistant provides a lot of personal growth experience and is easily balanced between other school work and my research.
cons: The undergraduates at Syracuse University do not care very much about their grades or academics. The department I was a teaching assistant for seemed to be divided among faculty between the priorities of research/publication and effective education.

pros: Helpful professors, great campus and research greatly supported. I always enjoy doing my research at this place. Probably it was because of my helpful professor.
cons: There arent any real huge cons about this place except they dont confirm the job until the semester starts and this leaves the students in a tensed state regarding his/her employment. Probably all other colleges are like this too. I'm not sure.

review_title: Not an easy place to work
pros: They are the largest employer in Syracuse and they have a good benefit package. It is also true that once you get a job, it is very hard to lose it as a manager.
cons: It is almost impossible to advance if you are good at your current position. I have tried for over 4 years to move to another department or school for a better position and I get the interview but never the position. The pay rate can be very low.

pros: Awesome management! Very fun environment to work in and the patients are very easy going and laid back. The office manager is very helpful if you have any questions . The dental assistant is extremely helpful with set up and tear down, helping with cleaning  rooms and setting up new trays.
cons: There are not very many downsides to working there. The equipment could be updated  to provide easier use of hygiene instrumentation.  More office meetings with the entire staff more often would be helpful to hear information from the entire team. That way we could improve office morale by understanding each others roles.

review_title: Great if you find the right lab
job_title: Student Research Assistant in Syracuse, NY
pros: The Psychology department has a variety of labs, some of them only really have you enter data but there are others that demand you to not only be a research assistant but to also manage the lab. You have the potential to get great experience.
cons: You can't get paid, but they do give you course credit (up to 3 credits per semester). Much better than taking a class.

pros:
The benefits are generous, if you choose to take advantage of them, and if you have children.  
It seems like there are a lot of opportunities to move within the University.
cons:
Micromanaging, bullying, and gossips poorly trained managers; it is not a work environment conducive for empowering excellence.  I've asked (HR and other administrative staff) the best practice to work around this- I was then retaliated against.  I let this be known, only to be told that "retaliation is taken seriously"- but nothing was done; retaliation is not taken seriously IME.  This is exactly why problems get worse.  There is a lot of gossip and bullying- perpetrated by management.  The consequence after reporting the behavior is retaliation against the tattletale.  It's an issue at Syracuse University.

Manager not willing to accept any criticism.  Manager not willing to accept any changes, or new ideas.  Get's visibly upset if an idea is presented; reprimands staff for interfering with the process, and being disruptive.  Manager will not confront issues directly- uses staff members to "communicate" messages to to other staff members. Inappropriate behavior.  The managers do not seem to be trained as managers- or poorly trained.  The work/life balance depends on your manager.

IME- the Culture here is mean spirited,  closed minded, with managers that bully with (poorly) veiled insults and microaggressions.   And slow. So slow, and inefficient, so much time wasted on irrelevant tasks.

pros: I loved being an RA at SU. Partially because my room and board was completely covered and partially because my staff was fantastic.
cons: The only negative party was that even though ORL tried very hard to meet our needs, they often missed the mark by cutting the budget in places they shouldn't have.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Port Jefferson Station, NY
pros: The dining halls can be a fun, relaxed environment, including some of the special dinners that feature foods of different cultures. Ernie Davis is by far the busiest of the dining halls, and has hands-down the coolest employees.
cons: You must always be wearing a hat or a hairnet, so if you care about your looks while working, perhaps scooping tuna onto a slice of pumpernickel isn't for you.

pros: Salary not bad, but the hours were so great, the pay figured low. My staff was great. Early manager was fantastic. I felt appreciated in the early years and was very loyal.
cons: Later manager did not treat me the same as the males. When I expressed my concerns, a campaign was started to fizzle me out. No real reason given. I feel it was due to me being a whistle blower and also male vs female inequality.

review_title: Great People, Inefficient and Uninnovative Management System
pros: Kind, hardworking environment - Many on staff at Syracuse University genuinely care for students and work very hard to provide a diverse array of experiences and developmental opportunities for them.
cons: Stagnant, confused - The flow of goal-setting, assessment, and decision-making inadvertently begs employees to avoid focusing on ultimate goals or invest in productive ways of improving outcomes. Mid-management cannot communicate goals clearly and tends to squash attempts to adapt.

review_title: An employer that truly values its employees
pros:
Benefits package is comprehensive, and very generous.
Very healthy attitude towards family/work life balance.
The students overall have a better attitude and work ethic than at the state school I was at before - SLIGHTLY better.
cons: Syracuse seems fairly well managed overall compared to other universities I have been with.  I dislike the culture of grant-seeking as a performance measure, especially because my research would not be enhanced by obtaining grants.  However this is more a complaint about academia in general rather than SU in particular.

pros: Productive environment. If you succeed in position, you will have many doors opened to you. Professor wants to see you succeed and will help you do so. Real experience
cons: Syracuse University has been stagnant for years, but it is now on the upturn as far as vision and plan. Still, there is lots of bureaucracy in higher education.

job_title: Video Production Assistant in Syracuse, NY
pros: The position was great for first and second year students interested in learning more about the technical aspects of broadcast journalism.  It was great to get experience working production before you get graded on it during class.
cons: Difficult to find a position where you work consistently enough to get paid on a regular basis.  Other than that I had no complaints.

pros: Job security is high, and the university provides a highly stable job environment. Benefits are competitive, and the workplace is relatively laid back. Room to advance is easily available if you are interested in "sidegrades", as the same positions appear across campus and moving to a different department or school can net you a few thousand dollars more with the new position.
cons: Layers of bureaucracy (Staff side of university) lead to innovation taking a long period of time, Wages on the lower end of the scale compared to state/national average

review_title: There is zero transparency and everything is secretive, many closed doors! Little autonomy due to hierarchy
job_title: Shared Service Representative in Syracuse, NY
pros: The dependent tuition and remitted tuition assistance is huge. Great retirement savings plan where company will contribute 10% after one year of FT service. There is a full benefits package offered.
cons: There is little autonomy and has zero transperency, lunch breaks are mandated at a specific time. The banafits package is well versed because the pay is not comparable at all. Plus there is a Max of a 2% raise each year..maximum.

review_title: Professor at Newhouse School, Syracuse University
pros: Great work environment, collegial faculty and administration, up-to-date facilities, and very bright students. Always pushing to keep current with world and industry events and processes.
cons: Pay raises are a joke, barely keeping pace with yearly cost-of-living increases. Negotiate firmly at hiring or you'll regret it later.

pros: It's nice to work on a college campus.  There are interesting people and things to inspire.
cons:
The pay is atrocious and adjuncts are treated like Kleenex - disposable.
No benefits.  If you work in one of the garages, or sell books at the bookstore, you qualify for benefits (health, tuition, etc) but if you are an adjunct - that is the FACE of the school to the students - you get nothing.  Demoralizing.

review_title: Syracuse University Online Platforms is fun
pros:
- Great work environment
- Fun people to work with
- Great boss
- Very flexible, I chose my hours
- Was offered a full time position after I graduated
cons:
- Other departments might not be as fun
- Pay could be better but not bad for a college job
- Mostly students worked where I did so some people were unqualified for the position

review_title: Good benefits, shallow pay, poor management.
pros: The benefits are good. Work is not very demanding and allows for a good balance of work and life. There is opportunity to grow.
cons: The pay is not that great. It can be difficult to get time off. There are stubborn people that you need to deal with.

pros: Stimulating environment, with opportunities to expand one's skill set and/or take on new challenges for those who strategically look for the the chance to do so. And, of course, tuition benefits for dependents and for employees are great. A great place to work for those who enjoy arts, cultural, and intellectual stimulation.
cons: Some entrenched attitudes and thinking in some pockets of campus. Very hierarchical environment among many of the higher-level administrative offices, which can sometimes make staff feel devalued or taken for granted.

pros: Syracuse has multiple competitive programs within the department, creating a high-performance environment. The facilities make sure that the external factors will help a program get to a higher level.
cons: The weather would definitely be one, especially for sports that are usually played outdoor. Parking possibilities are limited as well, since the students can park near the athletics facilities as well.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistants Treated Well by Individual Department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Syracuse, NY
pros:
- Department provided consistent funding for PhD program 
- Strong support for STEM students
- Access to a variety of extracurricular activities for professional development
cons:
- University treats PhD candidates like undergraduates, despite very different needs and stages in career (e.g. healthcare options, advice about off campus living options, career development options, etc). 
- Pay is extremely low despite high work load.

review_title: I don't regret choosing to come here
job_title: Graduate Student/Teaching Assistant/Researcher in Syracuse, NY
pros: Wide variety of research, great colleagues, supportive faculty & staff & administrators, great area, discounted insurance plans (not applicable to those on fellowships)
cons: As a TA, you do not have a say in which courses you are assigned to teach. You will take a lot more time to grade than administrators and faculty predict. Faculty sometimes slack on their duties, leaving you looking unprepared to the students.

pros: University knows what it's doing, and has the reputation and expertise to get things done.  It is an exciting, forward thinking place to be (or at least was, under Cantor's leadership; I have no experience with the new chancellor).
cons: Huge size can make it unwieldy to get new things done, and a dean with capricious or preferential priorities can wreak havoc on individual departments, slashing budgets and undervaluing work in a field he/she doesn't understand.

pros: If you are looking to pay for your kids college in few years, SU might be the route to go in terms of employers.
cons: Have to pay for parking, lacking interdepartmental communication at times, lots of nepotism, salaries are very low, it's cold here!!!!

review_title: Ok to work for if you are a "yes sir" kind of person
pros: Benefits package, pay rate was ok considering the other benefits you get including free education. A lot of different departments you can work under.
cons: Can be very cut throat. Management doesn't care about their employees advancing and bettering themselves, they only care about themselves. It can be very clicky and University contributions to benefits are on the decline.

pros: If you are interested and thinking of further studies, this is a good way to build up your research experience profile.
cons: Very low pay and sometimes you feel you are just a slave who needs to get his work done. Your professor can be very rude at times.

pros:
-Relaxed Environment
- Walking distance from campus
- Cool events and okay food occasionally
- Management tends to leave you alone some days
- I left the job when I did
cons:
- Highly dysfunctional staff structure
- Non-existent HR Structure
- Incomprehensible hierarchy of tasks and Job Descriptions
- Disorganized
- Too relaxed cuz everything gets done at the last minute
- Unpleasant co-workers

pros: Students and the predominance of the color orange
cons:
I'm surprised by the number of relatively positive reviews of SU. It is a difficult place to work.

- Innovation and new ideas are discouraged by people who have been there forever.  Don't bother - save your gems for a place that will appreciate them - they are out there.
- There are a lot of layoffs happening as I write this, most recently from the marketing department - something like 30 low and mid-level staff - the folks who actually do the work and who had been hoping for someone to come in and provide them with some direction and positive change. At least they got the "change" part.
- As a rule HR sucks and at SU they seem to embrace that whole-heartedly. Nothing like getting different answers depending on who you speak to or what mood they happen to be in that day. Personally, I was impressed by their inability to answer some of the most basic questions regarding benefits, tuition costs for staff, etc. It can't be easy to be in a job like that and remain so ignorant. That takes effort.
- If your boss doesn't like the performance review you are required to write about your hopes and dreams working there, they will re-write it for you and replace your truth with their lies.
- Parking is atrocious and expensive and SU makes you pay for it. Wear walking shoes and carry an umbrella is my suggestion. Schedule any outside appointments (doctors, dentist, etc.) at the very start or very end of the day, unless you want to factor in a long trek to and from your car.
- Management doesn't know who you are or what you do and they seem ok with that. No one really knows what it is that they do either.
- The folks that have been there for a long time have been through so many changes in management, that they don't latch on to the latest directives. Once new leadership comes in things will change anyway.
- Impressively ugly office working conditions. Near-constant construction ensures that your nostrils will be assaulted by solvent smells, your ears by drills, hammering, jackhammers, and your working space perpetually covered with dust.
- Good, talented, capable, and ambitious people are there for only as long as it takes to realize how much it sucks + the time it takes to find another job.
- There are no perks. I think they discount season tickets. But they don't let you use that pricey parking spot they make you pay for for events. You have to pay again for that privilege. 
- Syracuse as a city is in really bad shape. Crumbling infrastructre abounds.
